translated: The Sutra of the Prince's Auspicious Past Lives, Scroll 1
Translated by Zhi Qian, an upÄsaka from Yuezhi in the Wu region
The Buddha said, I recall my past lives, countless eons ago, when I was originally an ordinary person.
Since I first sought the Buddha's path, my spiritual essence has taken on form, wandering through the five realms.
One body dies and decays, and I take on another body, birth and death being without limit.
To illustrate, if all the grasses and trees in the world were cut down to make tally sticks, they could not count my past bodies.
A single eon is said to be the beginning and end of the universe, but the number of times the universe has formed and disintegrated since I began my spiritual journey is beyond reckoning.
The reason I feel sad for the world is that greedy thoughts flow on and on, drowning in the sea of desire. I alone wish to return to the source, so I encourage myself and stand out from the crowd.
Therefore, life after life, I endure hardship without considering it toil;
I keep an empty mind, enjoy tranquility, and have no desires or actions.

He gave away his own body, sincerely upheld the precepts, humbly practiced patience, bravely and diligently made energetic progress, and single-mindedly contemplated the subtle and learned the wisdom of the sages.

He was kind and compassionate to all under heaven, pitied the poor and suffering, comforted the sorrowful and distressed, nurtured all beings, rescued those in pain, served the buddhas, and accumulated merits and virtues beyond measure.

In the past, when DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha appeared in the world, there was a sage king named VijitÄvin who ruled the country of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«. The people lived long and happy lives, and the world was at peace.
At that time, I was a bodhisattva named MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«;
From a young age, I was intelligent and had lofty aspirations. I lived in seclusion in the mountains and forests, guarding the mysteries and practicing meditation.
Hearing that there was a buddha in the world, my heart was filled with joy. I put on deerskin clothes and set out to enter the country.
On the way, I passed through a village, where there were five hundred Daoist practitioners.
The Bodhisattva passed by, discussing the Way and expounding the meaning all day and night, and both teacher and disciple were delighted.
When it was time to part, the five hundred people each gave him a silver coin, which the Bodhisattva accepted.
Entering the city, he saw the people joyfully and busily leveling the roads, sprinkling and sweeping, burning incense.
He then asked the passersby:
'What is the reason for this?'
The passersby replied:
'Today the Buddha will enter the city.'
The Bodhisattva was greatly delighted and thought to himself:
'How wonderful!
Now I get to see the Buddha and can ask him about my wish.'
Just then, the daughter of the king passed by, named GopÄ, carrying a water pot and seven blue lotus flowers.
The Bodhisattva chased after her and called out:
Elder sister, please wait!
I would like to buy those flowers with a hundred silver coins.
The woman said:
The Buddha is about to enter the city. The king is fasting, bathing, and wants to offer the flowers. They cannot be obtained.
Please choose again.
Even for two or three hundred coins, they were unwilling to sell. She then took out five hundred silver coins from her bag and gave them all.
Gautami thought that the price of the flowers was very cheap, so she bought five hundred of them. Greedy for the silver treasure, she took five stalks of flowers and kept two for herself.
She turned back and had a suspicious thought:
What kind of practitioner is this, wearing deerskin clothes just to cover his body, not sparing silver coins and treasures to obtain five stalks of flowers?
She was delighted beyond the ordinary and chased after him, calling out:
Man!
Tell me the truth, can I get these flowers?
If not, I will take them from you.
The Bodhisattva looked back and said:
The price of the flowers ranges from one hundred to five hundred coins, which is decided by the market. How can I take them from you?
The woman said:
I am a member of the royal family, and I have the power to take them from you.
The Bodhisattva was embarrassed and said:
'I wish to offer it to the Buddha and make a vow.'
VaidehÄ« said:
'Good!
I vow that in my future lives, I will always be your wife, whether I am beautiful or ugly, we will not be separated;
Keep it in your heart and let the Buddha know.
Now I am a weak woman and cannot go forward, please lend me two flowers to offer to the Buddha.'
The Bodhisattva agreed.
Soon the Buddha arrived, and the king, ministers, and people all welcomed and paid homage to him, each scattering famous flowers, which all fell to the ground.
When the Bodhisattva saw the Buddha, he scattered five stalks of flowers, which all stopped in the air above the Buddha, like roots growing, none fell to the ground.
Later, he scattered two flowers, which also hovered above the Buddha's two shoulders.
The Buddha knew his sincere intention and praised the Bodhisattva, saying:

'The pure learning you have cultivated for countless eons, your subdued mind, your renunciation of life, your abandonment of desires and guarding of emptiness, your non-arising and non-extinguishing, your compassion without reliance, your accumulated virtues and practices, and your vows - you have now attained them.'
He then prophesied to him, saying:
'After this, in ninety-one eons, during the eon called 'Virtuous,' you will become a buddha, named Shakyamuni (meaning 'Able Sage' in the Indian language).'
The Bodhisattva, having received the prophecy, his doubts resolved and his hopes ended,
suddenly became free from thoughts and entered into concentration.
He immediately attained the pure forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas and rose up into the sky, seven tala trees above the ground. He descended from above and bowed at the Buddha's feet.

Seeing that the ground was wet, he untied his leather robe and wanted to cover it, but it was not enough to conceal the mud. He then untied his hair and spread it on the ground, allowing the Buddha to step over it.
The Buddha also praised him, saying:
'You are diligent and courageous. After attaining Buddhahood, you will be able to deliver gods and humans in the five turbidities without difficulty, just like me.'
The Bodhisattva served DÄ«paá¹ƒkara until his nirvÄá¹‡a.
Upholding the precepts and protecting the Dharma, he was reborn in the first heaven upon the end of his life, becoming the Four Heavenly Kings.

After the end of his heavenly life, he was reborn in the human realm as a wheel-turning sage king, a flying emperor - the seven treasures came by themselves: first, the golden wheel treasure; second, the divine pearl treasure; third, the purple-maned horse treasure; fourth, the white elephant treasure with a purple-maned tail; fifth, the jade maiden treasure; sixth, the wise mirror treasure; seventh, the sage guide treasure - for 84,000 years. At the end of his life, he was reborn in the second heaven of the Thirty-three Celestials, becoming Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra.
At the end of his life, he ascended to the seventh BrahmÄ Heaven, becoming the king of the BrahmÄ Heaven.
In this way, he ascended to become the Heavenly Emperor and descended to be the Sage King, each for thirty-six times, going around and starting over again.

As for his transformations, he manifested according to the times, sometimes as a sage emperor, sometimes as the patriarch of the Confucian forest, a national teacher, or a Daoist master, manifesting transformations everywhere, beyond record.
The Bodhisattva, for ninety-one kalpas, cultivated morality and virtue, studied the Buddha's mind, and perfected the practices of the ten grounds, being in his last life before Buddhahood.
Later, he was born in the Tuá¹£ita Heaven, becoming the teacher of the gods, his merits accomplished and his will fulfilled, with immeasurable spiritual wisdom.
When the time came, he was to descend and become a Buddha, taking birth in the country of Kapilavastu in India. His father was King Åšuddhodana, wise and benevolent;
his mother was MÄyÄ, of noble character and gentle virtue.
Kapilavastu is the center of the world of three thousand suns and moons, and twelve thousand heavens and earths.
The Buddha's majestic spirit is most venerable and most revered. One cannot be born in a borderland where the land is inclined to evil, so he abides in the center.
He transforms the ten directions. The Buddhas of the past all arose from here.
When the Bodhisattva first descended, he transformed into a white elephant with a sun-like crest.
He manifested himself entering through the right side while the mother was taking a nap.
When the queen awoke from her dream, she knew she was pregnant. The king immediately summoned the court astrologers to interpret her dream.
The divination said:
The virtue and morality to which it returns will bring blessings to the world. It will surely conceive a sage son.
While the Bodhisattva was in the womb, he was pure and free from foul odors.
Then the ministers and kings of the vassal states, hearing that the queen of the great king was pregnant, all came to offer congratulations.
The Bodhisattva, while in the womb, saw people outside paying homage, as if covered by a gauze curtain, and he waved his hand to remove it.
The intention of waving it away was not to disturb people.

When the queen was pregnant, the heavens offered her food and drink, which arrived naturally every day. The queen enjoyed them, not knowing where they came from, and no longer enjoyed the royal kitchen, considering it bitter and pungent.

On the eighth day of the fourth month, at the time when the morning star appeared, she gave birth through her right side, fell to the ground, and immediately took seven steps. Raising his right hand, he said:
In heaven and on earth, I alone am honored.
The three realms are all suffering, what is there to enjoy?
At that time, heaven and earth greatly shook, and the palace was completely illuminated.
Brahma, Shakra, and the devas all descended in the sky to attend.
The Four Heavenly Kings received him and placed him on a golden table, bathing the prince's body with heavenly fragrant water.

His body was golden in color, with thirty-two marks, and his radiance illuminated all the way up to the twenty-eight heavens and down to the eighteen hells, and the entire Buddha realm was greatly illuminated.
On this day and night, auspicious signs rained down from heaven, with thirty-two kinds:

First, the earth greatly shook and all the hills and marshes became level; second, the alleys naturally became clean and foul-smelling places became fragrant again; third, withered trees in the country all grew flowers and leaves; fourth, gardens
naturally produced wonderful sweet fruits; fifth, lotus flowers as big as cart wheels grew on land;

Sixth, hidden treasures in the ground all emerged by themselves; seventh, the precious objects in the hidden treasures opened and revealed their brilliance; eighth, garments in chests and trunks were draped on racks;
Ninth, the myriad streams and rivers stopped flowing and became still and clear; tenth, the wind ceased, the clouds dispersed, and the sky became clear;
Eleventh, the heavens rained fine fragrant dew on the four sides; twelfth, a divine pearl of bright moonlight
was suspended in the palace hall; thirteenth, the palace lamps and torches became unnecessary; fourteenth,
The sun, moon, stars all stopped and did not move. Fifteenth, the star Beidou appeared below, attending to the prince's birth.
Sixteenth, Åšakra and BrahmÄ's jeweled canopy covered the palace above. Seventeenth, the gods of the eight directions
held treasures and came to offer them. Eighteenth, heavenly food of a hundred flavors naturally appeared in front. Nineteenth,
a jeweled jar with a thousand mouths hung, filled with sweet dew. Twentieth, heavenly gods pulled a jeweled carriage with seven treasures and a canopy
to the palace. Twenty-first, five hundred white elephant cubs naturally surrounded the palace in front. Twenty-
second, five hundred white lion cubs came from the snow mountains and surrounded the city gate. Twenty-third,
heavenly court ladies appeared on the shoulders of the musicians. Twenty-fourth, the daughters of the dragon kings surrounded
the palace and stayed there. Twenty-fifth, heavenly court ladies held peacock feather fans and appeared on the palace walls.
Twenty-sixth, heavenly court ladies held golden jars filled with fragrant water and lined up in the sky.
27. The heavenly music of the twenty-eight heavens all sounded simultaneously, 28. The earth
27. The music of the heavens all descended and played simultaneously, 28. The hells all ceased and the poisonous pain did not continue, 29. Poisonous insects hid and auspicious birds flew and sang

, 30. Fishermen and hunters who had been hostile became kind-hearted at the same time, 31. Pregnant women in the realm gave birth to boys, and the deaf, blind, mute, lame, and those with a hundred illnesses were all cured,
32. The tree spirit appeared and bowed to the attendant.
At that time, those to the left and right of the field were all amazed and marveled at what had never been seen before.
The wife then wrapped him in white cloth, and the wet nurse raised him, naming him Siddhartha.
The king told his wife:
'The child's birth is not ordinary. There is a monk in our country named Ayi, over a hundred years old, with much knowledge and understanding of physiognomy.
Now I want to go with him to have him examine the child.'
The wife said:
'Excellent!'
He then had a white elephant harnessed, led by musicians, and went out to the path to give the ascetic a bag of gold and silver each, but the ascetic did not accept them.
He then undid the ascetic's robes and saw that he had thirty-two marks:

His body was golden in color, with a fleshy protrusion on the top of his head, his hair was dark blue, he had a white tuft between his eyebrows, a sun-like light on his neck, his eyes were dark blue, he blinked up and down together, he had forty teeth, his teeth were white and even, his cheeks were broad and square, his tongue was long and could cover seven finger-widths, his chest was full like a lion's, his body was straight, his arms were long, his toes were long, the heels of his feet were full and level, his hands and feet were webbed inside and out, his hands and feet had the pattern of a thousand-spoked wheel, his genitals were hidden like a horse's, his calves were like a deer's, his bones were connected like hooks and chains, his body hair curled to the right, a single hair grew from each pore, his skin was fine and soft, and did not absorb dust or water, and he had a swastika on his chest.
When Ayi saw this, he sighed even more, tears flowing, unable to speak from sorrow.
The king's wife was frightened and bowed, asking:
'Is there an inauspicious sign?
Please tell me the meaning of it.'
Raising her hand, she replied:
'It is auspicious, nothing unfavorable!
I dare congratulate the great king on the birth of this divine person.
The great trembling of heaven and earth last night was precisely for this reason.
The characteristics of the Buddha's appearance are said to be:

'If the king gives birth to a child with the thirty-two marks of a great man, he will become a wheel-turning sage king ruling the four continents, with the seven treasures coming by themselves, able to fly when walking, and naturally peaceful without weapons.
If he does not enjoy the world and abandons his family to pursue the Way, he will become a naturally enlightened Buddha, liberating the myriad people.'
Alas, I am already old and will go to the next world, not seeing the Buddha's appearance and not hearing his sutras, so I am grieving myself.

The king deeply knew his ability to discern signs, so he built a palace with three seasonal halls, each in a different place - in the rainy season he stayed in the autumn hall, in the hot season he stayed in the cool hall, and in the cold and snowy season he stayed in the warm hall. He selected five hundred courtesans, choosing only the most beautiful ones, neither fat nor thin, neither tall nor short, neither white nor black, with skillful talents and each proficient in several arts;
all adorned with white pearl treasures, with a hundred people taking turns guarding him.

In front of the hall, rows of sweet fruit trees were planted, with bathing pools between the trees, and in the pools were extraordinary flowers and thousands of different kinds of birds, all elaborately decorated and dazzling to the eyes, to please the prince's mind and prevent him from wanting to study the Way.
The palace walls were solid, and the sound of opening and closing the gates could be heard forty li away.
On the day the prince was born, a blue-clad servant in the king's household also gave birth to a black-headed child, and in the stables a white colt and a yellow lamb were born.
His attendant was named Channa, and the horse was named Kaá¹‡á¹­haka.
The king always ordered Channa to attend and provide the white horse for riding.

Seven days after his birth, his mother passed away. Because of the great merit and virtue of carrying the teacher of gods and humans, she ascended to the Heaven of the Thirty-three and received natural rewards.
The Bodhisattva originally knew that the mother's virtue was not sufficient to receive his homage, so he took birth from her as she was about to die.
When he reached the age of seven, he requested to study writing and went to the teacher's door riding a sheep cart.
At that time, a long time had passed since the sage, and two characters were missing from the writing. He asked the teacher, but the teacher could not understand and instead inspired his ambition.
By the age of ten, his wonderful talent became increasingly evident.
The prince had two cousins, brothers named Devadatta and Nanda.
Although Devadatta had the talent to surpass the world and was naturally difficult to match, he was arrogant and always harbored jealousy.
They invited him to play in the back garden, with a target attached to an iron drum, both pulling the bowstring and shooting at it.
Whenever the prince shot, he hit the drum.
The two were not as good, and considered it shameful.
After a long time, they invited him to wrestle in front of the king, demanding that the loser be doused with water.
The prince was kind and benevolent, and although he wrestled with his cousins, he did not hurt their bodies.
The two of them wrestled with him again after a long time.
Nanda pulled the elephant by the nose and dragged it to the courtyard;
Devadatta was strong and pulled it down;
The prince smiled and slowly approached the elephant, lifted it and threw it over the wall, causing no death or injury.
At this, the two realized they were not as good;
The king and those around him became even more aware that he was extraordinary.
At the age of fourteen, he asked the king to go out and play, wanting to observe his abilities.
The king ordered the left and right officials to lead and follow him.
Just as he was leaving the eastern gate of the city, the Heavenly Emperor transformed into a sick person, with a thin body and a large belly, leaning against the gate wall, panting.
The prince asked:
What kind of person is this?
His servant said:
It's a sick person.
What is meant by being sick?
He replied:

Generally, those who are sick are all due to wind and cold, either hot or cold. This person must have gotten this illness because of not being moderate in food and drink, and having irregular sleeping and rising.
The prince said:
How painful!
I am in a wealthy and noble position, with delicious food and drink, and I am also not moderate. I will also get sick. How is this any different?
He then turned the carriage back, feeling sad that all people are born with this affliction. How could one escape it just because of being powerful?
He then worried and did not eat, thinking to himself that he could not bear this illness.
The king asked his servant:
When the prince went out for a stroll, wasn't he happy?
He replied:
When I encountered a sick person, I was displeased by this.
The king then added five hundred courtesans to entertain him day and night.
The king was worried that he would study the Way.
After several years, when he was slightly better, he again said to the king:
Being confined in the palace for so many days, I wish to go out for a stroll.
The king could not refuse him, so he ordered the country in advance: The prince will go out, do not let the sick, the unclean, or the impure be by the side of the road.
The prince rode out of the southern city gate.
The Heavenly Emperor again transformed into an old man, with white hair, a hunched back, and walking with a cane.
The prince asked:
Who is this person?
His servant said:
An old man.
What is old?

He replied:ğŸ”½The years have passed, the body is weak, the hair turns white, the teeth fall out, the skin and flesh wither, the ears and eyes are deaf and blind, the four limbs are weak, and one is unable to walk. This is called old age.
'Old age means that the faculties are weak, the body changes and withers, food is not digested, vitality is weak, sitting and rising are extremely painful, and the remaining life is short.'
The prince said:
'What joy is there?

The sun and moon pass by, the seasons change, and the years go by. Things are born in spring, but wither and dry up in autumn and winter. Old age comes like lightning. How can one rely on a healthy body?

' He turned the chariot around and returned, thinking with pity that human life is not long in its prime, and that there is old age and sickness, whose pain is difficult to endure. 'I cannot stay in the world for long, suffering from this.' He was also worried about not eating.
The king regretted letting him out and increased the number of concubines to five hundred to entertain him.
After several years, he slightly improved and wanted to go out again.
The king said:
Every time you go out to observe, you return and are not happy, only worrying and becoming emaciated. What is the point of going out again?
The prince said:
I only think of their suffering. As I grow older, it will be my turn.
The king ordered throughout the country that no old, sick, or impure people should be by the side of the road.
The prince rode out through the western city gate.
The Heavenly Emperor again transformed into a dead person, with his family and children, holding banners and following the carriage, crying as they sent him off.
The prince asked again:
Who is this?
His servant said:
It is a dead person.
What is meant by dead?
He replied:
The dead are finished. Life has long and short, when blessings are exhausted and life ends, the breath stops and the spirit departs, the body is withered, therefore it is called death.
Human beings are all under one rule, there is no life that does not end.
The prince said:
Death is painful indeed, the spirit is troubled!
If life must have this suffering of old age, sickness, and death, who is not hot-hearted, pressed and approaching it, is it not also suffering?

I have seen the dead, their bodies decaying and transforming, yet the spirit is not extinguished. It follows good and evil deeds, and misfortune and blessings pursue it. Wealth and nobility are impermanent, and the body is a precarious city.
Therefore, the sages always regard the body as a calamity;
while the foolish ones cherish it, never tiring even unto death.
I cannot bear to receive life again after death, going and coming in the five realms, exhausting my spirit.
' Turning the carriage back, he felt pity for the people of the world who had these three kinds of suffering, and was unable to eat due to worry.
The king became even more unhappy and said:
'The country belongs to you. You should govern the people. Why do you think so far ahead, exhausting yourself with worries?
' He further increased the number of concubines to five hundred to entertain him.
When the prince reached the age of seventeen, the king took a wife for him. After examining several thousand famous women in the country, there was none to his liking.
The last woman, named GopÄ«, was upright, beautiful, and pure, the foremost in the world;
Her talent and virtue surpassed others, and she embodied propriety and righteousness. She was the former flower seller from a past life.
Although the prince accepted her, he did not interact with her for a long time. The wife's feelings of desire arose, and she wanted to be intimate with him. The prince said:
Always get good flowers and place them between us. Let's look at them together. Isn't that good?
YaÅ›odharÄ immediately prepared good flowers and wanted to be close to him.
The prince said:
Remove these flowers. Their juice will stain the bedding.
After a long time, he said again:
Get a good white cloth and place it between us. Wouldn't it be good for the two of us to look at it?
The wife immediately prepared the cloth, and again had the intention to be close to him.
The prince said:
Remove yourself. You are dirty and will surely stain this cloth.
The wife did not dare to be close to him.
The maidservants by his side all had doubts and thought he was impotent.
The prince pointed to his wife's abdomen and said:ğŸ”½In the future, you will give birth to a son who will leave home to become a monk and attain Buddhahood. He will be the most honored in the world.
'After six years, you will give birth to a son.'
And so she became pregnant.
Then the prince again requested to go out sightseeing.
He went out the northern city gate, and the Heavenly Emperor again transformed into a monk, wearing Dharma robes and holding a bowl, walking while looking at the ground.
The prince asked:
'Who is this person?'
His attendant said:
'He is a monk.'
'What is meant by monk?'
He replied:

'I have heard that the way of monks is to abandon family, wife, and children, to discard desires, to cut off the six senses, to keep precepts and do nothing. Their way is pure and clean. If one attains single-mindedness, then the myriad evils will be extinguished.
The way of single-mindedness is called arhat.

Arhats are true humans. Sounds and colors cannot defile them. Honor and status cannot bend them. They are difficult to move like the earth. They have escaped worries and suffering. They exist and perish freely.'
The prince said:
'Excellent!
This is truly delightful.'
He then turned the chariot around and returned.

He contemplated the Dharma and did not eat, thinking that the path is pure and that it is not suitable to stay at home. He should go to the mountains and forests to study the essence and practice meditation.
YaÅ›odharÄ was suspicious in her heart and knew that he wanted to leave. She did not leave his side whether sitting or standing.
When he was nineteen years old, on the eighth day of the fourth month, a deity appeared through the window with folded hands and said:
'The time has come for you to leave!'
The prince looked up and replied:
'There are guards pressing me. I want to leave but have no way to do so.'
The celestial spirit then caused his wife and all the female entertainers to fall asleep.
The prince slowly got up, listened to his wife's breathing, and looked at the female entertainers, all of whom were like wooden people. Their hundred joints were empty, like a banana plant.

Some had disheveled heads leaning on drums, their bodies slumped over lutes, supporting each other with pillows, their arms and legs hanging to the ground, their noses running, eyes leaking tears, and saliva flowing from their mouths.

The musical instruments, such as qin, se, zither, flute, and so on, were scattered around, and the birds such as the crested myna and mandarin duck, which were used for defense, were all soundly asleep.

The prince looked around and turned to look at his wife. He saw her entire body, with hair, nails, marrow, brain, bones, teeth, skull, skin, flesh, sinews, blood vessels, fat, blood, heart, lungs, spleen, kidneys, liver, gallbladder, intestines, feces, urine, snot, and saliva. On the outside, it was a leather bag, and on the inside, it was filled with foul things. There was nothing strange about it.
It was only forcibly perfumed with incense and adorned with colorful decorations.
It was like borrowing something that must be returned. It could not be kept for long. Half of the hundred years of life is spent in sleep.
Moreover, there are many worries and little joy.
Sexual desire destroys virtue and makes people foolish. It is not praised by the Buddhas and sages.
Therefore, it is said:
Greed leads to old age, anger leads to illness, and delusion leads to death.
If one gets rid of these three, one can attain the Way.
Thinking this in his mind, he then looked up at the star Altair. Halfway through the night, he saw the gods above, joining their palms and encouraging the prince to leave.
He then called Channa and told him to saddle the horse quietly. He lifted his robe and mounted the horse, hesitating in the courtyard, thinking that opening the gate would make a sound.

The Heavenly King Vaisravana, knowing his intention for a long time, then ordered the ghosts and spirits to hold up the horse's hooves and carry Channa, crossing out of the palace city and arriving under the rose apple tree in the king's field.
The next day, the palace was in an uproar, not knowing where the prince was. Thousands of carriages and tens of thousands of horsemen followed in a long line.
The king himself arrived at the field and saw the prince sitting under a tree from afar.
The sun was scorching hot, but the tree bent its branches to follow and shade his body.
The king was startled and realized that he was extraordinary. He did not know to dismount and pay homage. At that time, the prince also went forward to pay respects and said:
'Since I became your son, I have rarely left the country. Now, on this one occasion, why did the great king come to disturb me? I wish to return promptly.
The reason I want to leave the world is because of what I have seen. Affection and love are like a dream. The joy and happiness of the household will all end in separation.
Craving and desire are like a prison, difficult to escape from.
Therefore, it is said:

One obscures oneself with the net of desire, covers oneself with the shroud of love, binds oneself in a prison, like a fish entering a basket, watched by old age and death, like a calf seeking its mother's milk.
I always awaken myself with this, seeking naturalness, wanting to remove all suffering.
Those who have not crossed over, I want to ferry them across;ğŸ”½those who have not been liberated, I want to liberate them;
those who are not at ease, I want to bring them ease;
those who have not seen the Way, I want them to attain the Way.
Therefore, I want to enter the mountains to seek my wishes. When I attain the Way, I will return and not forget this vow.'
The king knew his resolve was firm and was at a loss for words.
He then returned to the palace and said to GopÄ:

'As for my son's mind, it is pure and difficult to move, like the earth. He does not enjoy wealth and nobility, nor does he aspire to rule the world. He only desires the Way and is determined to attain it.'

Then the prince, climbing a tree branch, saw a plowman plowing the soil and bringing out insects, which crows followed and pecked at. He felt pity for sentient beings, fish biting each other, the unrighteous causing great harm, dying and falling into evil realms, finding it difficult to escape.

Although the heavens are joyful, they are also impermanent. When blessings are exhausted, there is fear. When offenses arrive, there is also fear. Calamities and blessings follow each other, and birth and death continue for a long time.
Observing the human realm up to the twenty-eight heavens, the highest nobility without the Way, all correspond to the gates of hell.
The three evil realms have hundreds of kinds of pain and suffering. Joy and happiness are temporary, while worries and fears last long.
There is nothing strange between heaven and earth, and I can no longer be confused by desires.

He immediately mounted his horse, and as Channa walked in front for several tens of li, he suddenly saw the great god of the five paths named Bhisha, who was extremely fierce and strong, holding a bow on the left, an arrow on the right, and a sharp sword on his waist, dwelling at the crossroads of the three paths:
One was the heavenly path, two was the human path, and three was the path of the three evil destinies, which is where the souls of the dead must pass and see.
When the prince arrived, he asked:
'Which path should I follow?'
Bhisha was startled and threw down his bow, arrow, and sword. After a moment, he pointed out the heavenly path and said:
'This path can be followed.'
After walking for several tens of li, he encountered two hunters. The prince thought to himself:
'Since I have already abandoned my home and am in this mountain wilderness, it is not appropriate to wear precious clothes like an ordinary person, with desires and emotions.'
